title: nomatch
text: nomatch package designed use G-computation style estimation compute estimates marginal cumulative incidence observational cohort studies binary exposure time--event outcome. approach aligns target trial emulation framework (Hernan 2016) provides alternative matching methods, can suffer substantial efficiency loss. Estimation involves fitting two exposure-specific Cox models adjust baseline confounders. Predictions models used compute marginal cumulative incidence interventions exposure exposure. Effect measures risk differences, risk ratios, relative risk reduction also provided.

title: nomatch
text: examine use nomatch produce estimates effectiveness binary exposure. package can loaded follows: illustrate use package using simple simulated dataset, simdata, included package. exposition, assume dataset represents data observational vaccine study. practice, data disease settings can used well. first rows simdata can viewed follows: data contains one row per individual (ID) set individual baseline covariates (x1, x2). Information individual’s exposure encompassed 1) vaccination status (V), binary indicator values 1 = vaccinated, 0 = unvaccinated 2) time receiving vaccination (D_obs), numeric value vaccinated individuals NA unvaccinated individuals. data also includes right-censored survival outcomes(Y, event) Y represents follow-time outcome (e.g. infection death), event indicates whether individual experienced event values 1 = event, 0 = censored. assume time vaccination D_obs time outcome Y measured relative calendar date study start calendar time often important time scale vaccine studies due changing infection dynamics. settings, relevant time scale may time since enrollment meaningful event, age. Regardless choice time scale, time origin used define time exposure time outcome variables, well baseline covariates.

title: nomatch
text: learn real-world effectiveness intervention, can try compare incidence endpoint interest fixed time exposure individuals assigned active control exposure. assume exposed group consists initiators (e.g vaccinated individuals) non-exposed group consists non-initiators (e.g. unvaccinated individuals). analytical challenge setting start follow-unexposed group well-defined. One way circumvent issue imagine can assign individuals certain covariate group receive exposure (exposure) certain day. case, natural start follow-assigned day receiving exposure, just start follow-randomized trial day randomization. allows us define cumulative incidences intervention-day covariate group. day- covariate-specific cumulative incidences can marginalized (e.g. distribution exposure days covariates among observed exposed) obtain overall cumulative incidence estimates. can invoke nomatch function compute marginal cumulative incidences. , need provide several types arguments: data, outcome_time, outcome_status, exposure, exposure_time, covariates: Primary arguments providing dataset names variables dataset describe outcome, exposure, covariates adjust . immune_lag, timepoints: Arguments specify cumulative incidences compute. first, immune_lag, used compute cumulative incidences ignore events occur within immune_lag days; population interest defined subset individuals remain endpoint-free immune_lag days exposure. often used vaccine studies vaccine takes time induce immune response become effective. set immune_lag = 14 (2 weeks) pretend vaccine study, can also set 0 relevant setting interest. second, timepoints, specifies timepoints interest evaluating cumulative incidence. ’ve specified compute cumulative incidence infection/severity outcomes occurring within 30, 60, 90, ..180 days vaccination. boot_reps: Argument number bootstrap replications use since confidence intervals estimated cumulative incidences effect measures based bootstrapping procedures. Note use small number example runs quicly, boot_reps = 1000 recommended construct reliable confidence intervals interpretation. default, Wald-style bootstrap confidence intervals p-values returned. can print relative risk reduction (.e vaccine effectiveness) estimates simulated dataset. cumulative incidence estimates (cuminc_0 unexposed cuminc_1 exposed) ) effects (risk_difference, risk_ratio, relative_risk_reduction) also stored within fitted object. can examined via fit$estimates. confounders adjusted , resulting cumulative incidence/effect estimates can interpreted cumulative incidences effect observed clinical trial participants 1) similar observed exposed 2) enroll study distribution enrollments times matches distribution observed exposure times.
code: # Compute cumulative incidence  fit <- nomatch(data = simdata,                outcome_time = "Y",                outcome_status = "event",                exposure = "V",                exposure_time = "D_obs",                 covariates = c("x1", "x2"),                immune_lag = 14,                timepoints = seq(30, 180, by = 30),                boot_reps = 10) #> Bootstrapping 10 samples... #> Time difference of 3.47804 secs print(fit, effect = "relative_risk_reduction") #>  #>  Relative Risk Reduction Estimates  #> ==================================================  #> Call: nomatch(data = simdata, outcome_time = "Y", outcome_status = "event",  #>     exposure = "V", exposure_time = "D_obs", covariates = c("x1",  #>         "x2"), immune_lag = 14, timepoints = seq(30, 180, by = 30),  #>     boot_reps = 10)  #>  #> Result: #>   Timepoint Estimate 95% Wald CI: Lower 95% Wald CI: Upper Wald p-value #> 1        30    0.466             0.0902              0.686     0.086340 #> 2        60    0.395             0.2359              0.521     0.000925 #> 3        90    0.397             0.2594              0.508     0.000148 #> 4       120    0.339             0.2011              0.453     0.000448 #> 5       150    0.269             0.1387              0.380     0.001338 #> 6       180    0.172             0.0444              0.283     0.018627 #>  #> Use summary() for more details #> Use plot() to visualize results

title: nomatch
text: Internally, cumulative incidence estimates computed fitting two Cox models- one model unexposed one model exposed. model unexposed, time endpoint interest measured relative study start (chosen time origin). unexposed model includes individuals, exposed individuals censored time exposure, adjusts covariates. model exposed, time endpoint interest measured relative time exposure. model includes exposed individuals risk immune_lag days exposure, flexibly adjusting time exposure (default, using natural cubic splines four degrees freedom), well baseline covariates. summary estimation approach fitted models can obtained Cox models used predict day covariate specific cumulative incidences , default, marginalized observed distribution exposure times covariates exposed. weights used marginalization returned $weights component fitted object.

title: nomatch
text: Note plot , plotted pointwise confidence intervals, just usual 95% confidence intervals plotted timepoint. instead like make inference entire curve, need construct simultaneous confidence intervals. can using add_simulatenous_ci() function computes simultaneous confidence intervals given existing fitted object, provided bootstrap samples saved object (.e. keep_boot_samples = TRUE, default). function returns original fitted object updated simultaneous confidence intervals now save new object. simultaneous confidence intervals now stored fitted object. can also plot cumulative incidence curves simultaneous confidence intervals providing ci_type argument. Note simultaneous confidence intervals must computed plotting; otherwise, call error.  simultaneous confidence intervals indicate repeatedly construct simultaneous confidence intervals new samples data, 95% constructed simultaneous confidence bands contain true cumulative inicdence/effectiveness curve.
code: #Compute simultaneous CI fit_with_simul <- add_simultaneous_ci(fit, seed = 1234) fit_with_simul #>  #>  Risk Ratio Estimates  #> ==================================================  #> Call: nomatch(data = simdata, outcome_time = "Y", outcome_status = "event",  #>     exposure = "V", exposure_time = "D_obs", covariates = c("x1",  #>         "x2"), immune_lag = 14, timepoints = seq(30, 180, by = 30),  #>     boot_reps = 10)  #>  #> Result: #>   Timepoint Estimate 95% Wald CI: Lower 95% Wald CI: Upper Wald p-value #> 1        30    0.534              0.314              0.910     0.086340 #> 2        60    0.605              0.479              0.764     0.000925 #> 3        90    0.603              0.492              0.741     0.000148 #> 4       120    0.661              0.547              0.799     0.000448 #> 5       150    0.731              0.620              0.861     0.001338 #> 6       180    0.828              0.717              0.956     0.018627 #>   95% Simul CI: Lower 95% Simul CI: Upper #> 1               0.282               1.012 #> 2               0.457               0.801 #> 3               0.472               0.772 #> 4               0.527               0.830 #> 5               0.600               0.890 #> 6               0.697               0.983 #>  #> Use summary() for more details #> Use plot() to visualize results #Plot simultaneous confidence bands  plot(fit_with_simul , effect = "relative_risk_reduction", ci_type = "simul")

title: nomatch
text: Often, users may wish create custom plots. can done extracting estimates fitted object creating long tidy-style data frame. utility function estimates_to_df() takes estimates component fitted object reformats long dataset can used plotting. example, can create plot overlays cumulative incidence estimates two exposure types follows:
code: plot_data <- estimates_to_df(fit)  head(as_tibble(plot_data)) #> # A tibble: 6 × 8 #>      t0 term             estimate wald_lower wald_upper wald_se wald_pval wald_n #>   <dbl> <chr>               <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl>   <dbl>     <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1    30 cuminc_0          0.0116     0.00942    0.0144  0.109     NA          10 #> 2    30 cuminc_1          0.00622    0.00419    0.00922 0.202     NA          10 #> 3    30 risk_difference  -0.00542   -0.00981   -0.00103 0.00224    0.0155     10 #> 4    30 risk_ratio        0.534      0.314      0.910   0.271      0.0863     10 #> 5    30 relative_risk_r…  0.466      0.0902     0.686   0.271      0.0863     10 #> 6    60 cuminc_0          0.0379     0.0330     0.0435  0.0737    NA          10 plot_data |>    filter(term %in% c("cuminc_0", "cuminc_1")) |>    ggplot(aes(x = t0, y = estimate, color = term, fill = term)) +    geom_line() +    geom_ribbon(aes(ymin = wald_lower, ymax = wald_upper), alpha = 0.2, linewidth = 0) +    theme_bw() +   scale_color_discrete(breaks = c("cuminc_0", "cuminc_1"), labels = c("Unvaccinated", "Vaccinated"))+   scale_fill_discrete(breaks = c("cuminc_0", "cuminc_1"), labels = c("Unvaccinated", "Vaccinated"))+    labs(x = "Time since vaccination",        y = "Estimate",        title = "Cumulative Incidence Curves",         color = "Exposure Group",        fill = "Exposure Group")

title: nomatch
text: G-computation estimation approach generally expected produce similar point estimates simple analysis using rolling-cohort matching exposed individuals matched eligible unexposed individual time exposure key covariates. advantage G-computation estimation approach offers greater precision, may pecially valuable data involves smaller samples sizes rare endpoints. aid comparison two approaches, provide simple implementation matching approach uses rolling cohort design 1:1 exact matching Kaplan Meier estimation computing marginal cumulative incidences. Note functions implementing matching may take run large datasets. also intentionally limited scope, serving provide simple matching comparison.
code: # ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ # 3. Compare results with matching estimator  matched_cohort <- match_rolling_cohort(data = simdata,                                        outcome_time = "Y",                                        exposure = "V",                                        exposure_time = "D_obs",                                         matching_vars = c("x1", "x2"),                                        id_name = "ID",                                        seed = 5678)  matched_data <- matched_cohort[[1]]   fit_matching <-matching(matched_data = matched_data,                         outcome_time = "Y",                         outcome_status = "event",                         exposure = "V",                         exposure_time = "D_obs",                          immune_lag = 14,                         timepoints = seq(30, 180, by = 30),                         boot_reps = 10)  #> Bootstrapping 10 samples... #> Time difference of 1.429927 secs  fit_matching #>  #>  Risk Ratio Estimates  #> ==================================================  #> Call: matching(matched_data = matched_data, outcome_time = "Y", outcome_status = "event",  #>     exposure = "V", exposure_time = "D_obs", immune_lag = 14,  #>     timepoints = seq(30, 180, by = 30), boot_reps = 10)  #>  #> Result: #>   Timepoint Estimate 95% Wald CI: Lower 95% Wald CI: Upper Wald p-value #> 1        30    0.497              0.218              1.137      0.23324 #> 2        60    0.517              0.374              0.715      0.00346 #> 3        90    0.611              0.413              0.905      0.05192 #> 4       120    0.671              0.499              0.904      0.03018 #> 5       150    0.710              0.571              0.884      0.00935 #> 6       180    0.775              0.616              0.976      0.05517 #>  #> Use summary() for more details #> Use plot() to visualize results  # Plot matching vs proposed estimator - nomatch tends to have similar point estimates but narrower # confidence intervals compare_ve_fits(fit_matching, fit, effect = "relative_risk_reduction", labels = c("Matching", "nomatch (G-computation)"))

title: Estimate Effectiveness of Interventions in Target Trial Emulation Observational Studies Without Matching
text: minimal example shows use nomatch obtain cumulative incidences derived effect measures risk differences (RD), risk ratios (RR), relative risk reduction (1 - RR). use simple simulated dataset mimicking data observational vaccine study, although methods apply equally disease settings. Note dataset contains following: one row per individual (ID) set baseline covariates (x1, x2) exposure status (V) values 1 = vaccinated, 0 = unvaccinated. (Note: currently assumed unexposed group receive active comparator.) time vaccination (D_obs); unvaccinated individuals left NA. right censored survival data (Y, event) Y represents follow-time outcome infection, hospitalization death. event indicates whether individual experienced event censoring values 1 = event, 0 = censored.
code: #Load package library(nomatch)  # Example data simdata <- as_tibble(simdata) #for prettier printing   #View data head(simdata) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>      ID    x1    x2     V D_obs     Y event #>   <int> <int> <int> <int> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1     1     1     7     1     2    92     0 #> 2     2     0     7     0    NA   210     0 #> 3     3     0    11     1    35   210     0 #> 4     4     0    10     1     6   210     0 #> 5     5     1    11     0    NA   210     0 #> 6     6     1     7     0    NA    90     0 # Compute cumulative incidence and effect measures  fit <- nomatch(data = simdata,                outcome_time = "Y",                outcome_status = "event",                exposure = "V",                exposure_time = "D_obs",                 covariates = c("x1", "x2"),                immune_lag = 14,                timepoints = seq(30, 180, by = 30),                boot_reps = 10) #> Bootstrapping 10 samples... #> Time difference of 1.523599 secs  # Print main results  ## By default shows risk ratios  ## but all effect measures are computed and stored in the fitted object  fit         #>  #>  Risk Ratio Estimates  #> ==================================================  #> Call: nomatch(data = simdata, outcome_time = "Y", outcome_status = "event",  #>     exposure = "V", exposure_time = "D_obs", covariates = c("x1",  #>         "x2"), immune_lag = 14, timepoints = seq(30, 180, by = 30),  #>     boot_reps = 10)  #>  #> Result: #>   Timepoint Estimate 95% Wald CI: Lower 95% Wald CI: Upper Wald p-value #> 1        30    0.534              0.314              0.910     0.086340 #> 2        60    0.605              0.479              0.764     0.000925 #> 3        90    0.603              0.492              0.741     0.000148 #> 4       120    0.661              0.547              0.799     0.000448 #> 5       150    0.731              0.620              0.861     0.001338 #> 6       180    0.828              0.717              0.956     0.018627 #>  #> Use summary() for more details #> Use plot() to visualize results  # View additional details about the analytic approach  summary(fit) #>  #> ======================================================================  #> Analysis Summary #> ======================================================================  #>  #> Method:              nomatch (G-computation)  #> Evaluation times:    30, 60, 90, 120, 150, 180   #> Immune lag:          14  #> Adjusted for:        x1, x2  #>  #> Bootstrap:           10 replicates #> Confidence level:    95 % #> Successful samples:  10-10  (range across timepoints) #>  #> ----------------------------------------------------------------------  #> Sample: #> ----------------------------------------------------------------------  #> N total: 10000  #> Number of events: 1007  #>  #> N exposed: 4112  #> N exposed at-risk <immune_lag> days after exposure: 4045  #>  #> Distribution of exposure times among at-risk <immune_lag> days after exposure: #>  Range:  1 - 194 |  Median (IQR):  18 (11 - 32) |  Mean:  25.5 #>  #> ----------------------------------------------------------------------  #> Model for unexposed: #> ----------------------------------------------------------------------  #> N = 10000 | Number of events = 664  #>  #> Use '$model_0' to see model details. #>  #> ----------------------------------------------------------------------  #> Model for exposed: #> ----------------------------------------------------------------------  #> N = 4045 | Number of events = 265  #>  #> Use '$model_1' to see model details. #>  #> ======================================================================  # Plot cumulative incidence and effect measures over time  plot(fit)

what: Add simultaneous confidence intervals to effectiveness fit — add_simultaneous_ci
title: Add simultaneous confidence intervals to effectiveness fit — add_simultaneous_ci
text: Computes simultaneous confidence intervals, maintain specified coverage level across evaluation timepoints jointly. useful making inferences entire cumulative incidence effectiveness curve.

title: Add simultaneous confidence intervals to effectiveness fit — add_simultaneous_ci
code: add_simultaneous_ci(object, seed = NULL)

title: Add simultaneous confidence intervals to effectiveness fit — add_simultaneous_ci
text: object object class nomatchfit created nomatch() matching(). Must contain evaluations least 2 timepoints (length(object$timepoints)  > = 2), contain bootstrap samples (keep_boot_samples = TRUE fitting). seed Integer seed  ensure reproducible critical values simultaneous confidence intervals (relied random number generation). Default NULL (seed set).

title: Add simultaneous confidence intervals to effectiveness fit — add_simultaneous_ci
text: original nomatchfit object following modifications: estimates matrix gets additional columns describing simultaneous confidence interval bounds construction: simul_lower, simul_upper, simul_n simul_z_star Named vector containing critical values used term simul_excluded_timepoints Named list containing vector timepoints excluded simultaneous bands term  due insufficient bootstrap samples

title: Add simultaneous confidence intervals to effectiveness fit — add_simultaneous_ci
text: Critical values computed using bootstrap covariance structure across timepoints. timepoint 5% missing bootstrap samples, excluded simultaneous band warning issued.

title: Add simultaneous confidence intervals to effectiveness fit — add_simultaneous_ci
code: # Fit model with bootstrap samples fit <- nomatch(   data = simdata,   outcome_time = "Y",   outcome_status = "event",   exposure = "V",   exposure_time = "D_obs",   covariates = c("x1", "x2"),   timepoints = seq(30, 180, by = 30),   immune_lag = 14,   boot_reps = 100,   keep_boot_samples = TRUE ) #> Bootstrapping 100 samples... #> Time difference of 33.91398 secs  # Add simultaneous CIs fit_simul <- add_simultaneous_ci(fit, seed = 123)  # Look at results fit_simul #>  #>  Risk Ratio Estimates  #> ==================================================  #> Call: nomatch(data = simdata, outcome_time = "Y", outcome_status = "event",  #>     exposure = "V", exposure_time = "D_obs", covariates = c("x1",  #>         "x2"), immune_lag = 14, timepoints = seq(30, 180, by = 30),  #>     boot_reps = 100, keep_boot_samples = TRUE)  #>  #> Result: #>   Timepoint Estimate 95% Wald CI: Lower 95% Wald CI: Upper Wald p-value #> 1        30    0.534              0.346              0.826     3.63e-02 #> 2        60    0.605              0.480              0.762     8.15e-04 #> 3        90    0.603              0.499              0.730     4.25e-05 #> 4       120    0.661              0.557              0.784     1.00e-04 #> 5       150    0.731              0.628              0.849     4.62e-04 #> 6       180    0.828              0.721              0.950     1.45e-02 #>   95% Simul CI: Lower 95% Simul CI: Upper #> 1               0.308               0.927 #> 2               0.451               0.810 #> 3               0.475               0.767 #> 4               0.533               0.820 #> 5               0.604               0.884 #> 6               0.695               0.986 #>  #> Use summary() for more details #> Use plot() to visualize results  # Visualize plot(fit_simul, ci_type = "simul")

title: Compare two effectiveness fit objects — compare_ve_fits
code: compare_ve_fits(   fit1,   fit2,   effect = c("risk_ratio", "risk_difference", "relative_risk_reduction"),   labels = c("Method 1", "Method 2"),   ci_type = NULL,   colors = c("#F8766D", "#00BFC4") )

title: Compare two effectiveness fit objects — compare_ve_fits
text: fit1 nomatchfit object (typically matching()) fit2 nomatchfit object (typically nomatch()) effect effect measure plot next cumulative incidence plots. Either "risk_ratio"(default), "relative_risk_reduction"  "risk_difference". labels Character vector length 2 providing labels two methods. Default c("Method 1", "Method 2"). ci_type Character string specifying type confidence interval plot. One "wald", "percentile", "simul". NULL (default), uses CI type fit1. object ci_type = "", defaults "wald". colors Character vector length 2 providing colors two methods. Default c("#F8766D", "#00BFC4") (ggplot2's default red cyan).

title: Compare two effectiveness fit objects — compare_ve_fits
text: ggplot2 object three faceted panels showing cumulative incidence VE estimates methods.

title: Compare two effectiveness fit objects — compare_ve_fits
text: fit1 fit2 must significance level (alpha). function stop error alphas differ. cumulative incidence panels, y-axis limits shared across methods facilitate comparison. effect measure panel uses free y-axis scaling.

title: Compare two effectiveness fit objects — compare_ve_fits
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Fit both methods fit_nomatch <- nomatch(data = simdata, ...) fit_match <- matching(matched_data = matched_data, ...) # Compare with custom labels compare_ve_fits(   fit_match,   fit_nomatch,   labels = c("Matching", "G-computation")) } # }

title: Helper for constructing bootstrapped confidence intervals — estimate_bootstrap_ci
text: one_boot_function Function computes one bootstrap iteration returns bootstrap estimates one_boot_args List arguments pass one_boot_function ci_type Method constructing bootstrap confidence intervals. One "wald", "percentile", "". "wald" (default): Computes Wald-style intervals using bootstrap standard errors. See Confidence intervals section details. "percentile": Computes percentile bootstrap intervals. "": Computes returns Wald percentile intervals. boot_reps Number bootstrap replicates confidence intervals. Recommended use least 1000 publication-quality results. Use smaller values (e.g., 10-100) initial exploration. Default: 0 (bootstrapping). pt_est matrix point estimates, columns corresponding cumulative incidence effect measures, rows representing evaluation timepoints. argument must provided ci_type = "wald". Ignored ci_type = "percentile". alpha Significance level confidence intervals (Confidence level = 100*(1-alpha)%). Default: 0.05. keep_boot_samples Logical; return bootstrap samples? Default: TRUE. Must set TRUE user plans use add_simultaneous_ci() obtain simultaneous confidence intervals. n_cores Integer; parallel cores bootstrapping passed parallel::mclapply mc.cores. Unix-like OS ; available Windows. Default: 1.

title: Helper for constructing bootstrapped confidence intervals — estimate_bootstrap_ci
text: list containing following: ci_estimates list matrices, one term, containing lower upper confidence interval bounds n_success_boot numeric vector number successful bootstrap samples time point.(Success bootstrap samples result non-missing valid point estimates.) boot_samples keep_boot_samples = TRUE, list matrices, one term, containing bootstrap estimates. Rows bootstrap iterations columns time points. boot_reps = 0, returns NULL.

text: fit_model_0() fits Cox model estimate risk unexposed individuals original time scale. Includes individuals, censoring exposed individuals time exposure. default, model adjusted <covariates>, included simple linear terms. fit_model_1() fits Cox model estimate risk exposed individuals time scale time since exposure. Includes exposed individuals remain risk tau days exposure. Individuals additionally censored censor_time days exposure avoid extrapolation beyond time period interest. default, model adjusted <covariates>, included simple linear terms, exposure time included natural cubic spline 4 degrees freedom.

title: Fit survival models to estimate exposure-specific hazards for G-computation approach — fit_model_0
text: data data frame one row per individual containing columns named outcome_time, outcome_status, exposure, exposure_time, covariates. Missing values columns except exposure_time allowed. outcome_time Name follow-time outcome interest, .e. time either event right-censoring, whichever occurs first. Time measured chosen time origin (e.g. study start, enrollment, age). outcome_status Name event indicator outcome. underlying column numeric (1 = event, 0 = censored). exposure Name exposure indicator. underlying column numeric (1 = exposed follow-, 0 = never exposed follow-). exposure_time Name time exposure, measured time scale used outcome_time. Must non-missing numeric value exposed individuals must set NA unexposed individuals. formula_0 Optional right hand side formula model 0. default, uses covariates. tau Delay period events tau included. formula_1 Optional right hand side formula model 1. default, uses covariates plus natural spline vaccination day (4 df). censor_time Time exposure exposed individuals censored model fitting prevent extrapolation. default, censoring applied.

title: Main function to estimate marginal cumulative incidences and derived effect measures without matching — nomatch
text: data data frame one row per individual containing columns named outcome_time, outcome_status, exposure, exposure_time, covariates. Missing values columns except exposure_time allowed. outcome_time Name follow-time outcome interest, .e. time either event right-censoring, whichever occurs first. Time measured chosen time origin (e.g. study start, enrollment, age). outcome_status Name event indicator outcome. underlying column numeric (1 = event, 0 = censored). exposure Name exposure indicator. underlying column numeric (1 = exposed follow-, 0 = never exposed follow-). exposure_time Name time exposure, measured time scale used outcome_time. Must non-missing numeric value exposed individuals must set NA unexposed individuals. covariates Character vector covariates adjust fitting hazard models. Include known, measured confounders exposure censoring.  Covariates must measured defined chosen time origin. immune_lag Non-negative numeric value specifying time exposure (sometimes denoted tau) excluded risk evaluation period. argument primarily intended vaccination exposures, common exclude time vaccination immunity still building. Time must measured units used outcome_time exposure_time  (e.g. days) reflect biological understanding vaccine-induced immunity develops (usually 1-2 weeks). non-vaccine exposures,  immune_lag can set 0 (delay period evaluating risk). timepoints Numeric vector specifying timepoints compute cumulative incidence derived effect measures. timepoints expressed terms time since exposure use units used outcome_time exposure_time (e.g. days). values must greater  immune_lag correspond clinically meaningful follow-durations, 30, 60, 90 days exposure. fine grid timepoints (e.g., timepoints = (immune_lag + 1):100) can provided cumulative incidence curves time desired. weights_source Character string specifying type marginalizing weights use. Either: "observed" (default): use  empirical distribution exposure times covariates among exposed marginalizing weights. provides close alignment weights implicitly used matching. "custom": use user-specified weights provided custom_weights argument. custom_weights list(g_weights, p_weights) providing weights marginalizing time- covariate-specific cumulative incidences. Must following format: g_weights: data frame columns variables covariates exposure_time (time exposure), prob (probability exposure given time within covariate-group; sum 1 within covariate-group) p_weights: data frame columns variables covariates prob (probability covariate-group; sum 1 covariate groups.) ci_type Method constructing bootstrap confidence intervals. One "wald", "percentile", "". "wald" (default): Computes Wald-style intervals using bootstrap standard errors. See Confidence intervals section details. "percentile": Computes percentile bootstrap intervals. "": Computes returns Wald percentile intervals. boot_reps Number bootstrap replicates confidence intervals. Recommended use least 1000 publication-quality results. Use smaller values (e.g., 10-100) initial exploration. Default: 0 (bootstrapping). alpha Significance level confidence intervals (Confidence level = 100*(1-alpha)%). Default: 0.05. keep_models Logical; return two fitted hazard models used compute cumulative incidences? Default: TRUE. keep_boot_samples Logical; return bootstrap samples? Default: TRUE. Must set TRUE user plans use add_simultaneous_ci() obtain simultaneous confidence intervals. n_cores Integer; parallel cores bootstrapping passed parallel::mclapply mc.cores. Unix-like OS ; available Windows. Default: 1. formula_unexposed character specification right-hand side formula use fitting hazard model unexposed. set variables formula must identical set variables covariates. formula_exposed character specification right-hand side formula use fitting hazard model exposed. set variables formula must contain variables covariates exposure_time. recommended exposure_time modeled flexibly (e.g. using splines).

title: Main function to estimate marginal cumulative incidences and derived effect measures without matching — nomatch
text: Modeling. Two Cox proportional hazards models fit estimate exposure-specific cumulative incidences. unexposed model, outcome modeled original time scale includes individuals, exposed individuals censored time exposure. exposed model, outcome modeled terms time since exposure among individuals exposed remained risk tau days exposure. models adjust specified covariates help control confounding. second model also flexibly adjusts exposure time (default, natural cubic spline 4 degrees freedom) capture time-varying background risk. Predicted risks models marginalized specified exposure-time covariate distributions obtain G-computation style cumulative incidence estimates. Marginalizing weights. weights_source = "observed", marginalizing weights empirical distributions exposure times covariates among exposed remain -risk tau days exposure. weights returned nomatchfit object weights. can also obtained prior call nomatch() calling get_observed_weights(). Confidence intervals. Wald CIs constructed transformed scales: \(\text{logit}\) cumulative incidence; \(\log{RR}\) risk ratios/relative risk reduction, using bootstrap SEs. back-transformed original scale. transformation used risk differences. Parallelization. Bootstraps can parallelized Unix via parallel::mclapply() providing n_cores argument.

what: Compute conditional cumulative incidences from fitted Cox models — predict_from_model_0
title: Compute conditional cumulative incidences from fitted Cox models — predict_from_model_0
text: functions compute conditional time- covariate-specific cumulative incidence row newdata. predict_from_model_0() computes \(\psi_0(t_0; d, x) = 1 - S_0(d+t_0 \mid x)/S_0(d+\tau \mid x)\) calling predict(fit_0, newdata, type = "survival") times d + t0 d + tau. predict_from_model_1() computes \(\psi_1(t_0; d, x) = 1 - S_1(t_0 \mid d, x)/S_1(\tau \mid d, x)\) calling predict(fit_1, newdata, type = "survival")  times t0 tau.

title: Compute conditional cumulative incidences from fitted Cox models — predict_from_model_0
